answers.answer: Here is a website at one of the best hospitals in Minnesota http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/aortic-valve-stenosis/DS00418/DSECTION=treatments-and-drugsFor aortic valve stenosis there is a procedure that is done which involves a catheter in the neck with a balloon to open up the aortic valve.  It is easier than having to have open heart surgery and a valve repaired or replaced.  With your diabetes, you should talk to your doctors about if you are a candidate for this procedure.Do not stop taking your heart medication.  This is so important and the medication will help keep you out of the hospital.  If you stop taking your medication, you may end up in the hospital and that will be of more an expense for you than buying the medication.  The heart medication is so important and will help you to live a longer healthier life.  If you stop the medication, the pressure will build up in your heart, lungs and possibly the kidneys.  Enough of this pressure can cause heart failure with water retention.  Diabetes puts you are a higher risk for heart disease.  If the Zocor is not helping with the triglyercides ask your doctor if adding Zetia would help or switching to Vytorin.  Another options could be Lipitor.  The trigycerides are extremely important to keep them 150 or below.  If you eat red meat, limited the amount you eat or eliminate it from your diet.  Eliminating red meat definitely drops the triglyercides and LDL levels.Keep taking your medications as prescribed by your doctor.  If for some reason you cannot get the money for the medications, talk to your doctor about samples, talk to your church (if you are a member or attend), sell possessions, or talk to family and friends.  People are willing to help and more people together can think of solutions and ways to get the money for the medications that are so needed.  Take care.

question: I've been diagnosed with aortic valve stenosis and am having an echocardiagram this week as a follow up to one I had last year.  I've had a heart murmur since birth [I am know 61] and apparently my valve is getting more 'floppy' with age and I experience heart palpitations and slight pressure frequently.  I had an angioplasty and stent inserted into my main artery about four years ago and was put on Zocor although my trigs are always high.  I am also taking a channel blocker [have COPD so was switched from a beta blocker] and two hypertension meds plus baby aspirin.  Oh yes I have Diabetes II also and am taking two meds for that!  Feel quite overwhelmed and falling apart.  My question is this:  I will be losing my medical insurance in a month and have applied for state help and even SSD but all the paperwork takes months.  Are their dire consequences if I cannot take any meds?  Am thinking of ditching them all and taking supplements instead, like CQ100 and others.  Do any members here have such problems with health insurance coverage?  And what about pending heart valve surgery?  Do I delay that too?
title: Possible Surgery?
